They did it. I thought it wasn't possible nowadays, but they managed to prove me wrong. They had already made Horizon Zero Dawn an extraordinary game, but they did even better.

[h2][b]Graphics[/b][/h2]
Stunning from start to finish, from lush jungles and sun-drenched coastlines to ruined, overgrown cities and underwater depths teeming with life.

The level of detail in facial expressions, machines, and atmospheric effects is breathtaking. In my opinion, it's one of the most beautiful games ever released.

Each new region is a living painting. Diverse, vibrant, and meticulously constructed.

[h2][b]Story[/b][/h2]
The narrative continues Aloy's journey after the events of the first game. Now, her goal is to explore the Forbidden West and find a way to stop a mysterious plague that threatens to destroy all life.

The story is more ambitious, expanding the world and introducing new tribes, cultures, and characters with complex motivations.

Sometimes, it gets a little lost in technological explanations and dense mythology, but it maintains a strong human heart.
Aloy remains a charismatic and determined protagonist, but also shows enormous evolution compared to the first game.
The side missions are on a much higher level than in the first game, where many are true little stories with memorable characters and palpable consequences.

[h2][b]Gameplay[/b][/h2]
The gameplay has evolved and refined. Combat maintains the same balance between action and strategy, but with more options, weapons, and tactics.
The new machines are challenging and visibly distinct, each requiring a different approach and rewarding planning.
Beyond the improvements in climbing, it's now possible to swim at depth, use the glider, and even fly, giving a new freedom to exploration.
Melee combat has been improved, but still falls short of the thrill of confrontations with machines.

But resource gathering and crafting remain somewhat repetitive and very tedious, especially in the later stages, not to mention the excessive resources needed to obtain certain things.

[h2][b]Soundtrack[/b][/h2]
Another masterpiece of sound design. The music maintains the identity of the first game, but with even richer and more emotional themes.

The soundtrack perfectly accompanies each moment, from the serenity of exploration to the most intense battles.
Composers Joris de Man, The Flight, and Niels van der Leest once again deliver exemplary work.

[h2][b]Conclusion[/b][/h2]
Horizon Forbidden West is an exemplary sequel: it expands on everything the original did well and takes the experience to new heights, literally.

Visually stunning, mechanically refined, and narratively ambitious, it's a game that showcases the best that the open-world genre has to offer.

The Burning Shores DLC delivers to fans at the end something that only seemed theoretical in the first game, which only shows how much the world of video games has evolved.

Despite some excess of side quests and an uneven narrative pace at certain stages, it's an unforgettable adventure and an impressive technical achievement.

Guerrilla Games has mastered its craft and proves to be a threat to certain industry giants.

If you liked the first game, Horizon Zero Dawn, you will like this game as well.

They've improved on almost every aspect of the first game. The visuals are stunning, and they've made the animations and characters less stiff and much more natural. They've even gave Aloy a bit of a personality and a bit of an attitude as well which made her stand out much more as a main character.

Of course, the mystery and discovery of the first game is no longer prevalent as you already know why the world is the way it is and who Aloy is as well. This isn't the fault of this game of course, as with all sequels, that initial world building experience is done. Hence the story can be considered weaker in this sequel vs the first game. They do make up for it in what I would call the Mass Effect experience. No longer is Aloy the only character in the game - you will also learn a lot more about side characters as you help them solve their problems, and they yours in return.

Some minor bugs with occasional overlapping voice conversations, or out of order conversations or voice lines. Climbing is also a bit more restrictive as well, with occasion glitch in what's allowed or not. They changed the latter due to a new mechanic in the game, but it's not quite right. Aloy has a habit of thinking aloud as well, which is suppose to be a way to give hints to the player. But it's always very odd where she thinks one thing, and then does something completely different since the player is the one in control.

All in all, this game along with the first game had become one of my favourite games of all time. I just don't know what they will do in the future. There's only so much you can do with bows and arrows. Also, how many rocks can Aloy carry. :D

I've never had quite such a pronounced love-hate relationship with a single game. While HFW is a triumphant return to the even-more-beautiful world of Horizon, it's marred by a misguided attempt to add more mechanics that ends up with bloated, tepid gear and skill trees.  The world, characters, and most of the combat are all in the outstanding vein of the first game. There are moments of pure joy and wonder when all the elements combine perfectly.  But there are also many occasions of disappointment and frustration when it comes to the mechanics, especially compared to those of the first game.  (BTW, there's really no point in playing this game without first playing Zero Dawn unless you have no interest at all in the story.)  As you can tell from my time played, I did enjoy the game enough to complete it, including all the side content other than the Arena, but some of the terrible design choices made me question whether to proceed at times.

Hmmm.... Seems like my usual list of good, bad, and ugly points is 7383 characters too long, so I'll just summarise the first two categories...

-- THE GOOD --
- The world, characters, acting, sound effects, and music.  Especially the detailed and varied environment. 
- Story is pretty good, but not as good as in the first game.
- Mounted travel feels and sounds just right

-- THE BAD --
- Disappointing gear: meagre bonuses are usually cancelled out by significant weaknesses, such that acquiring new gear never felt very awesome.
- Nerfed weapons from the first game, making tripcaster and ropecaster almost useless
- Unnecessarily complex and unreliable new melee mechanics
- Aloy gets stuck on the smallest bit of terrain waaayyyyy too often, yet when you want her to stop and search a machine part she leaps over it with the agility of a gazelle

-- THE UGLY --
- Unlike in the first game, where every skill was significant and useful, many of the skills available in HFW are either 'meh' or 'why would I even want that?' With the way the tree is arranged, in many cases you are forced to take skills you don't want in order to get to the few that you might find useful.  And some seem downright insulting, like a reduction in damage if you trigger your own traps, or increased ammo amounts if you craft it only at a workbench.  Plus, there are no skills for several things you really could use, like a better dodge or getting up faster when knocked down in combat.  Speaking of which...
- Aloy takes about three months to get up after being knocked down in combat (which happens all too frequently).  Machine fights are much less fun than they were in HZD, because Aloy is much, much less agile while even the largest machines are vastly more nimble.  Oh and her dodge is less effective as well.  I ended up long-distance sniping most encounters to avoid this de-evolution.
- Many crashes to desktop claiming driver update required - tried all the solutions suggested on the web (drivers were already updated, tried rollback, increasing shader cache size, removing temp files and verifying game files, etc) to no avail. Oddly it was primarily when not much was happening or the game was actually paused, rather than during any intense graphics-oriented action.
- Some of the arena fights are ludicrously difficult, especially because of the pre-selected gear, the confined space, and Aloy's 'I've fallen and I can't get up' act.  Looking on the internet, it seems that these are 'puzzle fights' where you must win using the One Solution with a strict sequence of actions in a very short amount of time. A really sad aberration, given the normally quite flexible combat system.  And these are all presented sequentially, so you can't skip a fight to see what the next one is like.  The complete lack of fun for me here meant that some of the best weapons were locked away out of my reach.
- New melee combat moves that require precise timing that is almost impossible to achieve in actual combat when dodging is necessary. And there are so many of these new moves that it feels like memorising an entire Morse Code alphabet ('Was that short-short-pause-long or short-pause-short-long?').  It's nice that there are practice grounds for trying these out, but honestly almost every time I completed a training challenge I knew that would be the last time I ever tried that move.  Luckily (but also sadly) one can complete the game with almost no melee combat.
- Machine resources that have only a small percentage chance of dropping and can't be harvested through careful targeting. Aren't there tons of memes and videos from the past several decades of gaming demonstrating how everyone finds this silly and annoying?

I went into the first game not expecting much based on the premise, but the story and atmosphere managed to blow me away with its unique premise and quality all its own. It's those two parts of Zero Dawn, the story and atmosphere, which are severely lacking here with only a few exceptions within the main story-line.

The best way I can describe the problems this game has, it would be to say that it is far to eager to oblige. You will come across characters and situations that are brushed off as to not challenge Aloy and the player in a manner that becomes difficult not to notice. Characters will often either be entirely filled with positive or negative traits with little room for ambiguity, leaving most outside of the main cast feel by and large the same and you will know the outcome of plot-lines within a moments of beginning them.

Your friend is in town and doesn't like the local magistrate? Don't worry hes mean, overworks people, doesn't care about their safety, AND he caused the machine rampage in the area. Companion doesn't like his old rival turned chief? Don't worry no one in the tribe likes him and when you blow up their wall symbol of the clan's might, they'll all make fun of him for it and not care whatsoever for the cultural value of it, even the tribal elder. Faro's Tomb? Faro's villainy is amped up to 11 and nothing is added to his story of character that isn't moustache twirling evil. No incorrect and poorly justified pretense behind a horrible decision associated with his obsession to right his wrongs like he was in the first game, hes just a moustache twirling Saturday morning cartoon character here. The C.E.O. who forces you into the tomb? Turns out despite being a religious, cultural, and political icon no one cares that he's dead because 'He was an asshole anyway' and "he manipulated our beliefs" because people talk like that.

This extends to non mainline content as well with only a few exceptions. Nearly every situation is just unambiguous and will not challenge the player or world, people are just neatly divided into camps of good and bad. Tenakth elder's grandson joined the rebels? nah turns out hes a hero who was entirely trustworthy and turned himself in to save everyone. An Utaru village is under attack? Don't worry it's the rebels and we don't like them already. You need to break into a Tenakth prison to rescue a Carja? Nah don't worry the rebels recently took it over, and the character you came gets to leave with their head held high.

To be clear the exceptions are there, most of the main companions and Gaia are all great in their interactions between each other and Aloy. Especially Varl, and I didn't even like him in the first game. Horizon Forbidden West has several mechanical improvements over Zero Dawn and the graphics are pretty freaking incredible. I like how you can climb on the side of most cliffsides now.
Swimming underwater has never looked better.
Has a fantastic "wow" factor for the first 10 hours. But honestly that's all the good I can say about this game.

As the game goes on and you get over the "wow" factor, it just feels more and more boring and bland, even more so than the previous game. The world is way WAY too big, content is way too damn repetitive and the combat system doesn't have anywhere enough depth to keep things interesting despite the improvements. Melee combat still feels pretty bad, but you have combos now in comparison to Zero Dawn. Ranged combat is easily the best way to engage enemies but it gets really old after a while. Shooting off components on robot dinosaurs gets extremely repetitive quickly. The combat system would do better in a much smaller scale game. On top of that, bosses are way too damn spongey. I remember fighting a human boss at the (light spoilers) embassy and having to unload about 300 arrows into that guy's face in order to progress.

I haven't seen the story all the way to the end, not even close, but from what I've seen so far, the story is terrible. All of the intrigue and mystery that Zero Dawn had in its story is almost entirely absent in Forbidden West in favor of a very generic save-the-world plot. Every single character you meet either feels like a boring cliche, a walking caricature, or a young adult novel side character. Every single character has ZERO DEPTH (I do like Erend though, personality wise) except for Aloy, but her know-it-all attitude, monotone voice and excessive talking really got on my nerves after a while. The dismissive comebacks she has for every conversation were amusing at first but they ended up very grating.

Aloy comments over literally everything you do. Everything. Constantly points out the obvious, constantly spoils puzzles for you within literal seconds.
I somewhat liked her in Zero Dawn, but here, she is honestly very annoying.

The music honestly sounds very forgettable. One of the most forgettable soundtracks I've heard in years. I can't get a single song to come to my head or remember a single melody, whereas in Zero Dawn's case I can think of the main theme almost immediately.

There's this one minigame that I found that is basically Horizon's version of Gwent called Machine Strike. Just this one basic board game you can play and collect pieces for if you don't feel like fighting robot dinosaurs all the time. Machine Strike is ok, judging from my experience from the two matches I've played. It kind of reminds me of chess or checkers if there were much less pieces on the board and every tile you move onto has certain environmental abilities. I didn't play enough of Machine Strike to properly realize my opinion, but this minigame does exist in the game.

Ya know, I had hope that Guerilla would recognize what they did wrong with Zero Dawn and give the next installment their all, I was truly optimistic that Forbidden West was going to be one of the greatest games of all time but it really just doubles down on everything that Zero Dawn did wrong. 

The flaws are mostly the exact same as Zero Dawn's.

Incredibly beautiful world full of repititive and boring content.

Combat system that doesn't have enough depth and gets repetitive quickly. This is more of a foundational issue more than anything. There's only so much you can do to make shooting components off robot dinosaurs fun after a while. The core gameplay gets incredibly old in the long run.

Terrible storyline that doesn't have that intrigue Zero Dawn did on top of incredibly boring characters.

And like Zero Dawn, Forbidden West feels like 2 hour long tech demo stretched over 100 hours. Just doesn't make for a particularly good experience overall.

There's not enough done here to keep me interested in the series. 

Sorry, Guerilla. You seriously really need to step up your game next time. 

Downsize. Seriously. Zero Dawn and Forbidden West would be much better games if you guys didn't have a fetish for copy/pasting several miles of the same boring and repetitive shit all over these giant maps. 

If you guys cared about the quality of the content that the game has to offer as much as you did creating the incredible graphics, we would have one of the greatest games of all time.

Of course, you have many ways to always attempt stealth, but, say items like final boss of a cauldron, stealth is not exactly an option there ( for a full fledged fight ). Perhaps you can try to use smokebombs, but I never went that route, seemed a bit too much. When it comes to combat, i believe new additions were these statuses, like if you are smashed by a machine, you have ( and i counted ) up to 3,4 seconds to stand up, or sometimes you cannot run away if you are stunned. You can move, but, not at full speed. Perhaps I misremember but I do not recall such limitations in the first game that if you are hit, it takes you that much time to stand up ( to be frank, I played the game, the first one, 3.5 years ago so I may misremember ). Still, this seems to be this concept of poise ( like in souls game to which I have passed many ), but it just does not fit somehow. I found it constantly frustrating when fighting against apex monsters that if you missed the timing on a dodge, you have this annoying pause before you can stand up. 

Another aspect, which I believe was done horribly in the game, is the concept of stash. I fought and apex monster ( thunderjaw ). I had exhausted all my health ( even the extra health i gathered before the battle. I respawn at a campfire. In my stash I have 216 medical berries. Because it is just a campfire, I cannot access my stash :) Brilliant decision! In order to access stash one must teleport to either a shelter, or collect items again. The concept of a stash is, you should be able to access it most of the time, perhaps not during battle of course, but once you respawn after death, have access. Unfortunately, that was not the case. But this is not all! One you teleport to a shelter or somewhere else, besides waiting for 2 seconds for the teleportation icon to finish loading, it asks you for a confirmation whether you really want to teleport. I guess i sort of see the logic here. I mean, you teleport to a campfire that you selected and then you need to reaffirm, after waiting for a bit, that it is INDEED the campfire you wish to teleport too :) 
Climbing. I am not entirely certain but something has definitely changed in the mechanics. Here, I wish to really express my gratitude towards developers for adding the "guidelines" of where you can see where one can climb. In the first game, I believe there were no indicators so I did a lot of trial and error. It was fun however :) here there are, but, the most frustrating aspect is, when you climb, if you are off, at least in my case, by a millimeter, you cannot climb up. If you click once right or left, then you can climb. It was so funny because the small mountain i climbed was pretty much the same level of height but it just would not allow to me jump up. Not sure why. That was very appreciated when running away from a thunderjaw and he grabs your a.. because you did not move a millimeter to the right or left :) It was definitely appreciated :) 
Moving on. Underwater. As from the trailer, we know we will be able to do some underwater exploration which is phenomenal, but i found controls of going up and down, e.g. when hiding form monsters, were rather clunky. Not certain if it was due to a PC issue, but it was definitely not fluent, not as I had expected.
Mounting of machines. Here, I also wish to express gratitude to developers for the cool opportunity to be able to ride overridden machines. However, once more, the controls were clunky. First one can increase speed, as soon as you hit a small bump, all speed is gone. I know the machine can jump, since the machine has a habbit of attacking me whilst jumping, but a small rock, the machine cannot jump over :) I just really did not understand the mechanics there.
Lastly, the arena. I really wanted to share this. There is a mission, to fight against two machines ( new comer level roughly ). I fought, then, during the fight, two more machines appear from underground. SO whilst I attempt to kill the bigger machines, i constantly get attacked, pummeled into by smaller machines that were not on the menu :) I smiled of course and thought if my math was wrong. 2 machines means 2 enemies right? not 2 and then 2 more crawling up from the earth :)
All in all, considering these new mechanics into play and a lot of combat ( i play on Very Hard ) i think that there are quite a few things that desire improvement. I will attempt to finish the story but these constant issues with combat, odd teleportation mechanics, climbing cliffs where you need to be a precision "climber" so to speak, i just had hit a brakepoint of - "I had enough". I will take a break for now and finish this game later.
To conclude, I really wished to have a middle button here since the story and graphics are just to wonderful, however, in a game where you need to fight a lot, the mechanics need to be improved a bit, or, reconsidered perhaps. Therefore, for now, a thumbs down. 
Still, good job team for delivering this. Solid game. Thank you.

I've just finished all side quests, rebel camps, rebel outposts and I'm on my way finishing the drones and black boxes. I do enjoy this game, but the combat (specially the difficulty) design is so atrocious that I end up getting more annoyed than having fun while playing this game. THUMBS UP:

The soundtrack is not a masterpiece, but it's above decent and gives more emotion to combat against big machines. I loved the amount of weapon choices and playstyles we have access to in comparison to Zero Dawn. 

THUMBS DOWN:

- The story itself was more attractive in Zero Dawn though, as here we have a few edgy and boring millenia-humans, a bunch of cowards who hide themselves behind a suit, just like an armed man is suddenly courageous in real life but is in fact a petty chicken without a gun. The Tenakh arc is awesome, but that's it. I haven't played the DLC yet but I've had major spoilers about it. 

- I have nothing against above-weight characters, chubby characters or whatever, but her head is stupidly bigger than her body that I don't know if it's funny or lame to watch. There are a few outfits that you can clearly see her legs and arms, and they are so thin that her head looks out of place. Speaking of legs and arms, why is a nomad warrior who climbs mountains, swims a lot, hops on trees and fights machines so skinny? She spent and spends 99% of her life in the wilderness, her body constitution makes no sense to me. At this point Last of Us 2 Abby would make more sense. Also, Aloy herself is a bit less "human" in this installment with almost 0 personality.

THUMBS TOUCHING THE GROUND OF THE REALM OF SATAN:

- Pit Challenges: Making a mode encouraging melee is great, but when melee is completely useless against machines (unless you play on Story difficulty), there's no point in these challenges and all the dmc-like combos you tried to implement. NOBODY will ever use (or memorize) those combos on Rebel Camps/Outposts and more than 50% of the Warrior Skill Tree is a complete waste. The challenges are either extremely easy or extremely annoying/difficult. Honorable Mention to the Pit Master in Thornmarsh. How drunk was the guy in Guerilla team to come up with the idea of a fair melee combat bringing a coward p*ssy shield into the fight like a little girl? It was completely out of line and broke the immersion entirely, if that was in a tabletop RPG I'm pretty sure any player would call that guy a fricking pathetic coward. How do the Tenakth respect that coward as their Pit Master? Funny enough he kept almost insulting me for using a bow when he was hiding behind a shield, in again, a "fair" combat. COMPLETELY STUPID. The Enduring Fight was awesome though, but the story behind it kinda predictable and boring.

- Big Machines are Elden Ring God Superbosses with 0 balance: Getting into the things that led me to rate this game as a "I don't recommend it" I should note that I started my playthrough on Very Hard. I love hard games and I always pick the highest difficulty, the only reason I didn't pick Ultra Hard is because everywhere people say it is intended for NG+. Like I mentioned in the very beginning, the machines design is superb, all their details, their movements, it's awesome! But that is where their beauty ends. For the context, I'm now on the very last main quest with all side quests completed and all non-DLC machines killed with every of their variation, which includes Apex. I'm on the 4th part of arena (will discuss the worst part of this game in a few) having completed all the first 12 challenges on Very Hard as I refused to lower down the difficulty.

Most of the bigger machines break the laws of physics, the laws of common sense, they do a 180¬∞ turn during their skill movement while in the air in the middle of the animation if you dodge/jump/run...why  is that? Oh, it's because they are machines so they can. Why is this shellsnapper hitting me with its cannon when it's bound in the ground with ropecaster and stunned by shock? Oh, it's because it's a machine, so it can. Why is the same said shellsnapper literally teleporting dozens of meters with a burrow movement? It doesn't even have a drill. Oh wait, it's because it's a machine, so it can do whatever it wants.
It's not only the shellsnapper, every big machine can attack you even when immobilized and stunned...what the f*ck is that? It's because they are machines, so they can.

I've defeated all apex machines, including Tremortusk, Slaughterspine, and I can "farm" them efficiently, but they are still one of the worst things in this game (big machines in general) when it comes to combat. Who was the mentally disabled person who designed Tideripper? You can get stunlocked by its Tidal Disc's waters, which brings me to the question: Did you guys in Guerrilla have someone to review these atrocities? You agreed to that? Oh yes, they are machines, they can do whatever they want.

At this point I feel I'm fighting Divine Entity Versions of Transformers. I still can farm those easily, but the fun is 0 because I either cheese them with Ropecaster>>>Frost Ammo>>>Boltblaster, I stunlock them with Ropecaster and do whatever I want, or I struggle with totally unbalanced and unreviewed movesets like I did when I was low level with blue weapons. The game is extremely easy on anything below Hard Difficulty, and is extremely r-word on Very Hard and Ultra Hard, it's cheese or be cheesed.

- Why there is a fricking alligator living in harmony with anteaters? Why there are deers living in harmony with a fricking 10ft-height bear? Why every time I go to hunt a machine, instead of finding a horde of those machines, I find them accompanied by other "animals"? Because they are intelligent machines? If they are intelligent, why they attack people on sight like irrational animals? Why they behave like animals? It's so annoying to go fight a Frostclaw just to find 6 other machines of different types around it, it makes no fricking sense! If they are data meant to replicate animals, Gaia did it wrong, you don't see a bear partying with alligators.

- The Infamous Arena: There is a reason 90% of Horizon fans hate this mode. Who in their sane mind would allow such atrocity to be launched in the game? From the dumb metal shards cost to the nullification of certain builds (stealth) to the herp-derp Locked Loadout. NOTHING is fun about arena, NOTHING. FINISHING:

I'm a big fan of Aloy and her adventures, I love the post-apocaliptic USA, but I can't agree with the big amount of bad decisions taken in this game regarding level design and combat. I usually get more pissed than have fun while playing this game because the combat is so unbalanced that it makes me sick, and on the lowest difficulties the game has no challenge. I hope the third game is a better experience just like Horizon Zero Dawn was, and I'm looking forward to the Horizon MMO.

I do love everything that is not combat though, and the big head-emotionless Aloy (she was so cute in Zero Dawn). I'd give Forbidden West a 6.5/10

In a nutshell, it's an interesting concept with disappointing execution. Really good graphics though.

I played to see where the story goes next since the first game was really interesting. This game has some good new ideas but overall, a few things made it a poor experience:

- the combat is not good.
Alloy gets knocked down easily and often. This would be fine if there were a mechanic to get back on your feet quickly, but there isn't. Also, this makes a melee play style far less feasible than a ranged style. And even if you focus on ranged gameplay, enemy machines are extremely mobile and will 100% force you into melee situations very often.

- the game feels bloated and repetitive
The system for upgrading equipment was expanded too much or done in a way that makes upgrading gear feel like a chore. There are far too many animal parts and components to get. I'm no stranger to farming mobs to get loot for upgrades, that's just part of the genre, but this felt like such a slog . Upgrades also don't offer much increases in power, so it becomes less satisfying to play especially since the combat is often frustrating.

- the writing
Alloy can do no wrong, and she knows it. She's powerful and independent and nothing is a challenge to her; not seasoned warriors with superior equipment, not programming and computer sciences which are tough even for geniuses in our era. Characters are largely one-dimensional and the story feels like a glazing project.
